author: thegostep
content:
Touching on this question from <@!573787335796326400>

The problem with returning the beacon block with body back to the validator (as discussed by <@!363800010518822915> and <@!144468805697929216> on ethresearch) is that it will deanonymize the validator ip address to the relay. 

This is one of the two main design decision remaining for mev-boost: are we OK with leaking ip address of the validators to the relay? If yes, we can avoid messing around with custom libp2p channels, provide forkChoiceUpdated calls to the relay, and receive beacon blocks back from the relay. This reduces implementation complexity significantly but would require validators to setup reverse proxies if they want to protect against potential targeted dos attacks.

The way MEV-Geth works today is with this reverse proxy setup and miners have been happy with this approach. Similarly, I've investigated how other networks address this issue of deanonymization and for other POS chains it is quite common for validator IPs to be publicly known. Speaking to validators on these chains, they have not had any issues with targeted dos.

The current plan is to provide a "default" implementation which uses libp2p for sending messages to the relay, but to allow validators to enable direct communication if they are confident with their ability to maintain a secure reverse proxy (which I expect will be the vast majority of the network). From my perspective, it's up to the eth researchers + implementers to decide if it's worthwhile to build this libp2p stuff or if the reverse proxy approach is sufficient.
